narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class consisted of a weekly recorded lecture and a virtual seminar.

Instead of meeting for 1 hour and 50 minutes on Thursdays, we met for 75 minutes during our class slot and Prof. Greenwood recorded a 25-50 minute lecture for us to watch before class. We also had weekly readings and a 300-word discussion post due on Canvas each Wednesday evening.
This course shortened the live section and added a prerecorded video lecture we'd all watch before class each week

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned about the field of Black classicism by discussing how several Black authors from Africa, the United States, and the Caribbean have responded to/adapted the classics in their own work. We talked about a few different adaptations of ancient Greek tragedies, uses of the Odyssey in African American and Caribbean art and writing, several authors' responses to receiving classical educations themselves, and Greek tragedy and the Persephone myth in other works of African American literature. This course helped me learn about the role of the classics in Black cultures, and it challenged me to think about how artists respond to and remodel prior work through their own writings. I think this course taught me how to be a much more critical reader of adaptations and other works that respond to or take some kind of inspiration from other texts. It definitely helped me learn a lot more about literary analysis. Prof. Greenwood is INCREDIBLY knowledgeable, so the combination of her pre-recorded lectures and insights in class, our class discussions, and the assigned secondary sources was very helpful for learning more about literary analysis and prior scholarship on the works that we discussed in this course. In addition, I think this course encouraged me to write more creatively. I found the 300-word weekly discussion postings helpful because they encouraged me to turn out short and succinct pieces of critical writing relatively quickly.
I learned about how a variety of African & African American authors interpreted & were influenced by the Greek & Roman (mainly) Classics and also developed my writing and close reading skills

Comparing literature and culture. A greater understanding of the institution of classicism. Further development of my perspective and voice as a Black academic within a colonial apparatus of educaiton.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: interesting subject matter, engaging format, predictable and manageable workload, frequent and clear feedback.
Weaknesses: I wish there'd been more graded assignments throughout the semester.

Many strengths! The readings were all super interesting, and it seemed to me that they were well-chosen to give us a geographic and thematic range of works. These are works that you may not get exposure to in other courses, or that you wouldn't approach in the same way if you encountered them in another setting. I also thought it was very interesting that we didn't just read poetry, plays, and novels, but also nonfiction accounts relating to classical education. Prof. Greenwood's expertise in the subject matter is also a huge strength of this course. Not only is she an extremely knowledgeable classical scholar, but it was also always clear from her pre-recorded lectures and our class discussions that she knows a great deal about the context for each of the works that she assigned and about other relevant scholarship and artistic works. Overall, this course provides unique perspectives on Black literature and intertextual dialog that I don't think you'll find elsewhere. 

Even if I didn't think so every week, I've decided that the weekly discussion posts were also a strength of this course. I think they challenged me to write creatively and succinctly, and they also made sure that I spent some time thinking independently about the readings before our class meeting, not just reading through whatever the secondary sources might have said about the text(s) we were discussing that week. I liked that Prof. Greenwood asked us to compile and lightly edit the posts for submission at the end of the semester, since this was a nice way to look back on what we had learned over the course of the semester. Another strength was that Prof. Greenwood sometimes gave us written comments on our posts, and she often brought them into the discussion in class. 

For improvements, I do think that some weeks there was too much reading. The week about classics and the "uplift of the race" in the United States was particularly heavy, as was the week with Invisible Man (I almost wish we'd devoted two weeks to that novel). Trying to cut down some of the reading in a few places may help students think about them more critically instead of just struggling to get through a large volume of reading. (I think the reading quantities were a bit uneven, so some weeks weren't a problem and some were just particularly heavy.) However, did like that we had Antigone assigned for the week about The Island. Reading the ancient Greek play was useful for me personally, since I don't have an extensive background in the classics (a few other students seemed to be in a similar situation to me in that regard). I wonder if it would be good to have Oedipus Rex assigned as well, and/or maybe excerpts of the Odyssey or other works when relevant. I wouldn't want these to get in the way of any of the other texts that we read, though, since they are all so important! But if it's possible to work the classical plays/excerpts in from time to time without the reading load becoming overwhelming, I think that could be helpful for some students. This is just something to consider.

Strengths: I loved how thoughtful, passionate, and caring Professor Greenwood was! She was open to everyone's interests in sending discussions sometimes unexpected directions. Her weekly video lectures helped give us both background information and interesting interpretations and relations between works and authors and ideas, which really did help make discussion richer. We also got personalized feedback on discussion posts basically every week, so we really did get a lot of helpful feedback.

Weaknesses: She did end up moving it back, but having us read The Invisible Man and turn in an essay the same week was a bit daunting!

The cap for this course was 10 people, which meant everyone was able to participate fully in discussion. I particularly enjoyed the class on Romare Bearden's collages. The readings were also really good, except the weeks with full novels or longer readings assigned (Invisible Man, Beloved, Omeros) were difficult, and it felt like we weren't able to fully cover the entire work or go in-depth in those class discussions. Perhaps splitting those readings into two weeks or assigning specific chapters / passages could be considered.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was well organized for virtual learning. The recorded lectures and virtual seminars were an effective combination.

I liked that Prof. Greenwood decided to make our discussions on Thursdays 75 minutes and to supplement them with the pre-recorded lectures. I found the background material provided in the lectures very helpful, and it was nice to be able to refer back to them when I was writing the final paper. I think that in a virtual setting, 75 minutes is a good amount of time for a discussion-based course. The other seminar I had this semester that kept the full 1hr50min meeting time was exhausting over Zoom, but it's not nearly as difficult to stay focused for a 75-minute class discussion. Sometimes it did feel like we weren't able to discuss as much in class as would have been ideal, though, so that may be a tradeoff.
I thought this course was really well organized for online learning

One drawback of zoom is that discussion is basically students talking one-on-one teacher while everyone listens, and seldom do we get to discuss with each other. Breakout rooms is a solution to this, but maybe also on the weeks there are presentations, each presenter can lead the discussion for a few minutes after presenting. This would give students more chances to be actively discussing with each other.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It's a really interesting way to approach classics and Professor Greenwood is a great teacher.

Yes, if you're interested in the material! It's a niche class, but I think that if you're interested in African American studies and/or Black diasporic studies, or if you're interested in the classics and world literature, then this would be a really good course to take. This class offers unique perspectives on artistic production, and I felt like it really pushed me to think about writing and Black cultures in ways that I hadn't before. Sometimes it was very challenging, but I hope I got a lot out of it. Prof. Greenwood is a great professor--she's extremely knowledgeable, very nice, and also very well organized. I think that her comments on our discussion posts and papers were always thoughtful and helpful. It's very clear that she's put a lot of thought into the design of this course, so I really think that it's a unique opportunity that's worth taking if you get the chance and you think you'd enjoy the material!
Yes! If you have a chance to take a course with Professor Greenwood, you absolutely should. It's hard to imagine getting her rich perspective from many other Classics professors at Yale.
